Impact of High Oil Prices on Growth and Inflation

1 Mr Yee Jenn Jong asked the Minister for Trade and Industry (a) how is the Government preparing Singapore for a scenario of rising crude oil prices given increasing tensions in the Middle East and Iran's decision to halt oil exports to certain countries; and (b) how will persistent high oil prices impact our growth and inflation forecasts.

The Second Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr S Iswaran) (for the Minister for Trade and Industry) : Mr Speaker, Sir, let me first highlight that the geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Iran's decision to halt oil exports to certain European Union countries have not significantly affected global oil supply at this point in time. The affected EU countries have started turning to alternative sources of crude oil supply to meet their needs. Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil producer and exporter, has also made commitments to increase oil production to compensate for any shortfall in supply due to the Iranian oil curbs.

Page: 1726

Although the developments in Middle East are evolving and highly uncertain, they have not had a major impact on our domestic costs at this juncture. As such, we are maintaining our 2012 GDP growth forecast at 1% to 3% and the CPI inflation forecast at 2.5% to 3.5%. The Government will continue to closely monitor the situation, and take these into account when reviewing its GDP growth and inflation forecasts. Nevertheless, we recognise the risk that a deteriorating situation in the Middle East may cause oil prices to raise. Indeed, UK Brent oil prices have risen from around US$110 per barrel at the end of last year to more than US$120 per barrel recently, close to the recent peak level registered in April 2011 when the Middle East and North Africa faced significant political unrest.

Should this trend continue, we, as a small economy almost wholly reliant on imported energy, will face higher energy prices. Businesses, particularly in energy-intensive sectors such as transport and chemicals, could face rising costs. Electricity and gas tariffs may also increase as the price of natural gas, which is used for electricity and town gas production, is pegged to oil prices, which is the usual practice in the Asian gas market. To enhance our resilience against supply and price shocks in uncertain conditions, diversification of our energy sources is key. Diversification will help ensure that we continue to have secure and competitively priced energy supplies to support our growth. We will continue to explore the development of viable alternative fuel sources. For example, we are building a Liquefied Natural Gas, or LNG, terminal which will provide access to the global gas market. Electricity import is another option that we are considering, which could allow Singapore to tap into new energy options that may be unavailable or economically infeasible in Singapore. The Government also works with industry players to explore alternative feedstock options to increase the competitiveness of the more energy-intensive industries, such as refineries and crackers, in Singapore. For example, the Economic Development Board (EDB) is exploring using Liquefied Petroleum Gas as a complementary feedstock to naphtha.

Beyond supply-side solutions, the Government also promotes more efficient energy use, and encourages businesses to play their part in using a scarce and precious resource wisely. We provide grants for energy efficiency projects, administer programmes which encourage energy efficient design and technology, and work closely with companies to uncover opportunities for energy efficiency through audits and benchmarking studies. Adopting energy efficiency practices helps companies cope with energy price volatility in the short term, but also prepares them for a future that will increasingly be energy constrained.

Mr Yee Jenn Jong (Non-Constituency Member) : Sir, I thank the Second Minister for the answer. One supplementary question. Does the Minister foresee that there may be some additional short-term measures that may be needed when the oil prices stay very high for a long time and inflation becomes unbearable, and if so, what may this be?

Mr S Iswaran : Mr Speaker, Sir, there are many suppositions and hypotheses in the Member's question. I would repeat what I said in my reply, which is that we are closely monitoring the situation and if indeed there is a substantive impact that requires government actions, we will then take the necessary steps.

Productivity and Innovation Credit

Ms Jessica Tan Soon Neo (East Coast) : Sir, I beg to move,

That the total sum to be allocated for Head M of the Estimates be reduced by $100.

Mr Chairman, restructuring our economy and the need for companies especially SMEs to improve productivity was a topic that many of the Members of this House spoke about over the last few days as we debated the Budget. Singapore still remains quite a distance behind most developed economies in terms of productivity. To be able to address the issue, SMEs must be the focus as they are a significant part of our economy. To achieve this, businesses have to invest in their people, processes and leverage on technology to create higher value jobs for Singaporeans and those who work in Singapore. This will require funding.

The Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) which was introduced in 2010, together with the enhancements announced in this year's Budget will be valuable in providing companies especially SMEs the impetus for investments in innovation and restructuring of businesses. It will help to address the cashflow required for substantial upfront expenditure required for restructuring. I was heartened to hear from Deputy Prime Minister Tharman when he summed up the Budget that no effort would be spared to help SMEs in this drive to restructure their businesses. While I did get his assurance that SMEs will not be required to read all the 66 pages of the PIC Guide to apply for the scheme, I do, however, want to ask that we still give some serious thought to simplification of the application process and the access to PIC. Apart from the complexity of the scheme and the application process for the PIC, the feedback I received from the various dialogues with business leaders indicates that the qualification criteria for PIC are fairly rigid. In the ICPAS Pre-Budget 2012 Survey, although PIC was the top initiative that was utilised by respondents, there was still a significant difference between widespread awareness and actual utilisation of the incentive scheme. To encourage greater adoption of PIC by SMEs, I think that it would be worthwhile to review the qualification criteria and to simplify the application process.

A suggestion made to enhance the adoption of the scheme is to have an exclusion list on what would not qualify rather than a qualifying list. Another feedback is the conditions to qualify require substantive and fairly significant expenditure and are almost always expenditure-based. As mentioned, the PIC forms in themselves are not too difficult, the challenge is in understanding the criteria which companies are required to check, validate and get the appropriate approvals from relevant agencies against their other tax criteria.

Has there been streamlining of processes to improve the handling of citizen/business applications and requests? Like the experiences that the hon. Ms. Indranee Rajah shared in her Budget debate speech, many of us will have similar scenarios on the ground that we could share, where there could have been more effective partnerships and approaches taken by the public agencies to address issues on the ground. While our agencies are effective and efficient in each of their areas of responsibilities, cross agency collaboration can be improved. Is there a coordinated effort across the relevant Government agencies to drive better collaboration and hence improve productivity and positive citizen experience?

Can the Minister share the progress that the Government has made to drive a Whole of Government approach to achieve the strategic outcomes for effective citizen services and national issues? What measures have been put in place to encourage and ensure greater collaboration and accountability across agencies to be more effective at the national and citizen level?

The Government has adopted a fiscally prudent approach and has maintained a balanced Budget. I would like to ask what measures are being taken to ensure fiscal prudence and discipline of public agencies. What measures are in place in our public agencies to ensure fiscal prudence, strengthening of the procurement process and strong management of projects to achieve intended outcomes and fiscal accountabilities? What is being done to ensure a balance between operational efficiency and risk of fraud? How will fiscal disciplines be maintained while allowing for flexibility in the approach?

Project Finance Company

Mr Chen Show Mao (Aljunied) : Based on the recommendations of the Economic Strategies Committee (ESC) in 2010, Budget 2012 announced that Temasek has put together a consortium of reputable financial institutions to establish a specialised project finance company (PFC). I would like to understand more specifically how the PFC will benefit our companies.

First, the PFC will aim to have about 80% of its portfolio comprising cross-border projects with significant Singapore-based corporate participation. What does the Government mean by "significant Singapore-based corporate participation"? Does significant participation means majority ownership? And how does the Government define a Singapore-based company for this purpose? Does it have to be headquartered in Singapore, listed on the SGX or majority owned by Singaporeans? Is a Singapore subsidiary of a foreign multinational company considered a Singapore-based company?

I hope the Government will have clear guidelines on this. The ESC has made it very clear what the gap is and that is to facilitate cross-border financing for our companies that are investing in large-scale projects overseas, because project finance is significantly less developed in Singapore than elsewhere and capabilities of our local banks in this area are relatively limited. These concerns do not exist in the case of companies that can access project financing outside Singapore's financial system.

Second, the ESC highlighted that as foreign export/import banks (EXIMs) remained largely nationalistic, Singapore companies are currently disadvantaged in this aspect. In order to help our companies compete on an equal footing, will the PFC adopt a similar approach to the foreign EXIMs? The Singapore Government will provide backing to the PCF by guaranteeing it debts. Will the PCF require some form of participation by Singapore companies in every project that it finances?

Managing Reserves

Mr Inderjit Singh (Ang Mo Kio) : Sir, I would like to raise one point regarding our Sovereign Wealth Funds (SWFs). The reason we have two SWFs – GIC and Temasek – which operate separately as private funds with larger risk appetites is because they are supposed to target different types of investments. However, in recent times, they are starting to look very similar and are also investing in almost similar assets. This is not a good trend as we may be over-investing and lack diversification in our investments, which could come back and haunt us doubly hard if these sectors are hit by problems. We have seen this when we were hit by the number of investments in financial institutions by both entities in the last few years.

The reason this is happening is due to a lack of coordination. I think this problem first started when Temasek first reviewed its charter in 2009 in conjunction with its 35th Anniversary where it started developing a more fund manager-like charter and added greater international outlook to its investments.

MOF should review and redefine the charters of both GIC and Temasek and also play a more active role in coordinating their investment philosophies. This oversight will allow MOF to ensure that there are no overlaps on the types of investments that GIC and Temasek make. Sir, the SWFs have a huge responsibility. Besides helping Singapore in its economic strategies, they also have to ensure that they do not dilute the reserves through their investment philosophies. Although their investments should not be politically influenced, I think MOF should not shy away from carrying out a coordinating role as it would be beneficial for Singapore as a whole.

Tax

Sir, on tax, I would like to raise three broad points on tax changes in this year's Budget. First, I would like commend the Government for introducing the GST Vouchers on a permanent basis in this year's Budget. While GST credits paid out in previous years provided some relief for households, there was, nevertheless, some apprehension on the part of these Singaporeans. Their main concern was in anticipating if these credits would come the following year – so there was a sense of uncertainty at that time. The voucher system has provided the much needed assurance to these households in this regard.

In the past, Sir, I have argued about the case for removal of GST for basic necessities. A grassroots leader of mine recently asked me why the Government zero-rated GST for gold investments, a luxury item, and not for basic necessities. I would like to seek clarification why the Ministry of Finance opted for the vouchers instead of removing the GST from the basic items. I would think that the GST Voucher system is administratively more cumbersome than the zero-rating of GST of basic necessities.

Sir, on corporate taxes, the tax changes to the Mergers and Acquisitions scheme, where companies can now claim up to 200% tax allowance on the transaction costs incurred is a welcome initiative as many companies in the past, particularly the smaller ones, were put off by the relatively high transaction costs. This is therefore a step in the right direction but I urge the Government to review the $100,000 cap, so that it will stimulate M&A deals of bigger nature. At the present cap, companies would qualify for up to $34,000 of tax allowance a year based on a 17% corporate tax rate, and may not be enough to stimulate the very large deals as the transaction costs associated with those are high due to a larger pool of professionals working on them.

Our personal income tax is already one of the most competitive but I thought that it was about time that we rationalise the top personal income rate tax with the corporate tax level so that both are aligned.

Sir, adjustments to the Earned Income Relief for the older workers is a welcome move to help them save for their retirement. But I am surprised that there was nothing done to ensure that this problem was nipped in the bud this time and does not carry forward to the future generations of Singaporeans. The Government could have perhaps encouraged additional tax deduction for voluntary CPF contributions, or reviewed the Supplementary Retirement Scheme to allow greater tax deductible contributions so that younger Singaporeans can now already start saving for their retirement. By not addressing this problem at this time, we will be revisiting it at every generation and we may have to continue using more Government top-ups rather than equipping them to be self-sufficient. That would have been in line with this Budget for the future – about doing something now that will help them in the future without Government's intervention.

Tax Relief: Handicapped Family Members

Dr Chia Shi-Lu (Tanjong Pagar) : Mr Chairman, I would like to ask for the Ministry's support in recommending an increase in the Handicapped Child Relief (HCR) and the Working Mother's Child Relief (WMCR) for handicapped children. Currently, the difference between the Qualifying Child Relief (QCR) for a normal child and HCR is only $1,500 – $4,000 versus $5,500. But surely, the difference in the cost of bringing up a normal child compared to a handicapped child is significantly more than that. In addition, the QCR or HCR, together with the WMCR, is currently capped at $50,000 per child regardless of the condition of the child. I hope that the Ministry will consider a higher relief for the WMCR for the mother of a handicapped child.

On a similar note, the difference between the tax reliefs for supporting a normal spouse and a handicapped spouse is only $1,500 a year – $2000 versus $3,500. The tax relief for the care of each handicapped sibling is similarly only $3,500 a year.

I think this year's Budget is notable for the extra benefits it extends to working handicapped Singaporeans, but I feel that there should be something for the caregivers of non-employed handicapped Singaporeans as well. So in view of the hardship and challenges, not to mention the additional financial burdens borne by such families, I hope the Ministry would consider increasing these tax reliefs.

Full Convergence with International Financial Reporting Standards

Mr Ong Teng Koon (Sembawang) : Mr Chairman, Sir, in 2009 the Ministry announced that by 2012, we would work towards the full convergence of the Singapore Financial Reporting Standards with the International Financial Reporting Standards for the Singapore incorporated companies listed on the Singapore Stock Exchange.

The Accounting Standards Council was to give a review last year. However, the International Financial Reporting Standards are currently undergoing very significant changes partly due to its agreement to converge with the US Generally Accepted Accounting Principles – a response to the global financial crisis and improvement for changing business transactions. These changes in International Financial Reporting Standards have to be implemented by businesses when they are finalised and issued. Can the Ministry provide an update on the timetable for convergence? Will there be increased compliance cost because of the convergence? And given the Ministry's plans to develop Singapore into an international accounting hub, so that infrastructure, networks and human capital resources in the accounting arena are well placed to help businesses, will there be measures to help the affected businesses?

Productivity and Innovation Credit Scheme for Self-Employed

Mr Seng Han Thong (Ang Mo Kio) : Sir, the previous PIC scheme applied only when there was an employer and employee relationship. It is noted that the PIC scheme announced in Budget 2012 also includes training of agents, such as insurance or real estate agents. Would this mean that the PIC scheme also covers the training of other self-employed persons such as the taxi drivers?

I urge the Government to apply the PIC scheme on taxi companies which invest in the training of their taxi drivers who are self-employed, just like the Government has made an exception for taxi companies to claim for tax deduction on expenditures incurred under the Drive and Save Scheme in the previous Budget.

More Effective Productivity and Innovation Credit Implementation

Ms Tan Su Shan (Nominated Member) : The PIC scheme aims to improve productivity through innovation and upgrading of the labour skills. My question is: do the people who should know about it, know about it? What is the take-up rate? And do the sectors or the segments of people who need it most qualify? And can some people actually game the system?

Page: 1733

One, awareness and take-up rate. The SME Development Survey 2011 done by the SBF showed that although 65% of firms that are aware of the PIC, only 24% avail themselves of it. Is this because the qualifying criteria are too strict? Feedback so far: the scheme is good, it is generous but it is a bit convoluted.

Two, more targeted help. Different sectors have different factors that affect productivity growth. If we are serious about facilitating productivity growth across different sectors, we may need to target those where productivity levels are falling most. According to an MCI survey recently, whist productivity grew in the manufacturing sector by 8.7%, it fell in the service sector, particularly infocomm's business services and finance down 3%. So what are we doing to ensure that the PIC scheme reaches out to these sectors that most needed?

Three, more flexibility. For the PIC to benefit the low-income segments, we may need to be more flexible. Requiring a staff size of at least three local employees will exclude a significant proportion of micro enterprises, including social enterprises, who may not have regular or sufficient cashflow to support full-time salaries. It may also exclude hawkers or many of those in the bottom 20% of our income segments, and these are the people who need the most help. The Government had stated that the PIC is for all businesses, but instead of staff size criteria, would the Government consider more targeted ones such as auto qualification for the scheme if you have been in your second year of business, for example? Or perhaps, one for one cap on each equipment type per staff?

Lastly, gaming the system. Is the Government confident that firms which qualify under the current scheme are not gaming the system? For instance, is there no reselling of equipment subsidised by taxpayers? And as foreign companies are also eligible for the PIC, how can we be sure that the equipment subsidised by Singapore stays in Singapore?

Productivity in the Public Sector

Mr Laurence Lien (Nominated Member) : Mr Chairman, according to figures released in the Budget highlights, actual headcount in the public sector rose 14% in just four short years from FY2006 to FY2010, and is poised to increase significantly more this year. Based on my own estimations, it would probably exceed 20% in the six years from FY2006 to FY2012. And these numbers do not even include headcount in Government-linked institutions and companies like the restructured hospitals and the universities. At the same time, the Government is promoting productivity and innovation in a very tight labour market. So my question is whether the public sector is setting the right example for the rest of Singapore.

In last year's COS, then Second Minister for Finance mentioned that it used its manpower management framework to allocate manpower resources prudently, and it allows headcount growth to meet our growing challenges at a rate no more than Singapore's resident labour force growth rate. According to MOM figures, the resident labour force grew 9% from 2006 to 2010, yet the public sector headcount grew 14%. May I ask for an update on how the manpower management framework is working?

I am particularly concerned because the rest of us in the private and non-profit sectors are really suffering from labour shortage. The lack of human resource is the greatest challenge in the non-profit sector where I work. And I think Government is at an unfair advantage because every time it cannot attract enough staff, it can just raise the pay, and just last month, we saw that. When my little NPO loses people, many of them go to Government bodies.

Before the public sector goes on a hiring spree, I would like to urge the civil service to go on a major productivity drive and really examine whether staff are using their time meaningfully and productively. I spent many years in the public service, and I can tell you that the generous staff numbers is something that the non-profit sector can only dream about. And besides, the Prime Minister is asking the civic society to do more!

Just as is the case in the private and public sectors, there is a lot of inertia and I understand that it is often difficult to reap productivity savings. Mr Chairman, let me now touch on issues related to an effective and efficient Government, beginning with the management of our reserves, which Mr Inderjit Singh raised. He had suggested that Government plays a coordinating role between GIC and Temasek to ensure that there are no overlaps. His key concern is that even as GIC and Temasek manage their own portfolios on a diversified basis, taking them together, there could still be concentration risks in the overall Government portfolio. Mr Inderjit Singh's question is a valid one and I should assure him that the Government does, in fact, systematically review the risks in its overall portfolio. We do this by considering the Government's whole portfolio of assets invested by the three entities – MAS, GIC and Temasek. We monitor for concentration risks in the whole portfolio, and whether there is appropriate diversification in terms of asset classes, sectors and geographies. We also assess the impact on the whole portfolio of various adverse global scenarios across medium to long-term timeframes, to ensure that the risks to the whole portfolio are not excessive. MAS, GIC and Temasek, in fact, operate at different parts of the investment risks spectrum, even if there is some overlap. They engage in different investment strategies and take different degrees of risks.

MAS, as a central bank, is the most conservative of the three. A significant majority of its diversified portfolio is in low risk and liquid investments. GIC's mandate is to preserve and enhance the real value of Singapore's foreign reserves over time. GIC's portfolio is well-diversified across asset classes including equities, bonds, real estate, natural resources and some other asset classes. It is also highly diversified internationally. Temasek's mandate is to create and deliver sustainable returns for its shareholders over the long run. This has remained Temasek's mandate even after its Charter was revised in 2009. Temasek is an equity-only value investor. It takes concentrated stakes from time to time but its portfolio remains diversified and it is also invested across sectors and geographies. I should add that Temasek's strategy of actively investing internationally begun much earlier than 2009 – it made the shift in 2002 and has since achieved more diversification by reducing its previously heavy concentration in Singapore assets.

The Government does not decide on how each investment entity should manage its own portfolio. Their respective boards and professional management teams are responsible for those decisions. The Government's role is therefore two-fold: first, and foremost, we ensure that these investment entities have competent boards to oversee how their respective management teams execute their investment mandates. We also ensure that these entities have proper mandates and objectives. Second, based on the overall risk profile of the Government's whole portfolio, we decide how Government capital should be allocated among the three entities. Further, we ensure that GIC, Temasek and MAS are sensitised to Government's considerations with regard to these overall risks. It is therefore not an auto-pilot system. We have a governance structure for looking at our Whole-of-Government assets within the system and for monitoring the overall risks and returns. It is a structure that has worked well and that we will keep improving.

Mr Chairman, MND goes beyond public housing and HDB. Through AVA, BCA, CEA, NParks and URA, our work affects Singaporeans' larger quality of life, current and in the future. As this is my first MND COS, let me briefly highlight three key challenges that will shape our workplan over the next few years. First, how do we go beyond building homes to building communities? We used to live in kampongs where everyone knows everyone. There is a general consensus on how we can live together. We take care of one another – gotong royong – as well as our little kampong.

As we moved into city living, many things improved. But, yet, we became more isolated from one another even when we lived more closely together. And that is the irony of it. Much of the kampong spirit is lost. Many do not even know their neighbours. We lost some of the basic courtesy we used to have for one another. We care less about our neighbours and the community spaces that we share.

There are many reasons for the loss of the kampong spirit. But we need to find ways to encourage residents to own their community and to care for one another again. To be sure, there are areas in Singapore where the kampong spirit remains strong. I am most proud and happy that the kampong spirit in my constituency is very strong. Yishun South as well, so said Er Dr Lee Bee Wah. We need to find out how such spirit can be replicated in many more places.

Second, how do we prepare for the silver tsunami? In 20 years' time, one in five Singaporeans will be over 65 years old; one in 20 over 80. If I am still alive, I will be one of the one in 20. Many will be living alone because many Singaporeans have chosen not to get married. The whole texture of society will change. The built environment will need to evolve to accommodate the needs and aspirations of older Singaporeans. Certainly, we will need more nursing homes, more day care centres, more day rehabilitation centres, better wheelchair access, etc. But there is much more that is needed. There is no one size that will fit all. We do not know exactly which will work more effectively. We just need to try many models to see which one works best for us.
